questions.question: Which of the following factors will increase the risk of a patient developing gastriccarcinoma?
What is the most common site of gastric adenocarcinoma in the Asian population?
questions.explanation: The most common site of gastric adenocarcinoma in the Asian population is the antrum. This isbecause H. pylori infections are relatively more prevalent in Asian countries and are associatedwith carcinoma of the body and distal stomach than the proximal stomach.However, in western countries, the proximal stomach is the most common site. This is attributedto a lesser prevalence of untreated H.pylori infections and a greater burden of chronic GERD andobesity in western countries.448

questions.question: A man presents to the hospital with a 3-day history of haematemesis. Upper GI endoscopyreveals multiple gastric polyps and a positive urease breath test. Which type of polyp is hemost likely to have?
questions.explanation: The given history and investigations are suggestive of Helicobacter pylori infection. The polypsmost commonly associated with H. pylori infection are hyperplastic polyps.Hyperplastic polyps usually regress following H. pylori eradication therapy.Benign gastric polyps are classified into two groups:• Neoplastic:• Adenoma• Fundic gastric polyp• Non-neoplastic:• Hyperplastic polyp (most common)•Inflammatory polyp•Hamartomatous polypNote: The terms hyperplastic polyp and metaplastic polyp refer to the same lesion, however,'hyperplastic polyp' is a preferred term.

questions.question: An elderly patient who presented with abdominal discomfort and weight loss was diagnosedwith type I gastric cancer according to Lauren's classification. Which of the following is not442true regarding this condition?
questions.explanation: Type I gastric cancer is associated with hematogenous spread.Lauren's system classifies gastric cancer pathology as either type I (intestinal) or type II (diffuse),based on differences in etiology, epidemiology, and pathology. Intestinal type of gastric cancershows hematogenous spread, whereas diffuse-type shows transmural and lymphatic spread.

questions.question: Which of the following genetic mutations is least likely to be seen in a patient with anintestinal type of gastric cancer?

options.B: Loss of heterozygosity in the APC gene
options.C: Under expression of transforming growth factor α
options.D: Loss of heterozygosity at the bcl-2 gene

questions.explanation: In the intestinal type of gastric cancer, several growth factors may be overexpressed, includingtransforming growth factor α, the epidermal growth factor, and vascular endothelial growth factor(VEGF).Molecular pathologies seen in Intestinal type:• Mutation or loss of heterozygosity in the APC gene or in ẞ-catenin•• Inactivation of p53• Loss of heterozygosity at the BCL-2 gene• Microsatellite instabilityMolecular pathologies seen in diffuse-type:449• Mutation of E-cadherin• Inactivation of p53

questions.question: A man, presented with multiple episodes of non-bilious vomiting containing undigested foodparticles within one-hour post meals. On physical examination, he was found to be anemicand cachexic. CECT abdomen revealed diffuse infiltration of a neoplastic growth into thestomach wall. What Bormann's classification does this tumor belong to?
questions.explanation: The history and investigation findings are suggestive of gastric outlet obstruction caused by adiffusely infiltrating type of gastric carcinoma. This is commonly known as linitis plastica and it isclassified as type IV in Bormann's classification system.

questions.question: A patient was found to have a tumor extending up to 1cm below the gastroesophagealjunction on EUS. According to the Siewert classification, which stage of carcinoma does shehave?
questions.explanation: The patient is likely to have a Siewert type II lesion. This include tumors with the center located 1cm above and 2 cm below the GE junction.• Type I: Adenocarcinoma of the distal esophagus - the epicenter of the lesion is 1-5 cm above GEJ•• Type II: Adenocarcinoma of the cardia - the epicenter of the lesion is up to 1 cm above and 2 cmbelow GEJ• Type III: Subcardial type adenocarcinoma - the epicenter of the lesion is 2-5 cm below GEJ

questions.question: A woman presented to the gastroenterology OPD with significant weight loss, fatigue, and abloating sensation for the past 8 months. A detailed workup was done, and she was diagnosedwith early gastric carcinoma. All of the following structures can be involved in this stageexcept:
questions.explanation: In early gastric cancer, there is no involvement of muscularis propria.Gastric cancer can be classified as early and advanced gastric cancer, based on the extent ofinvolvement.Early gastric cancer involves:• Mucosa (including muscularis mucosa)• Submucosa• +/- lymph nodesAdvanced gastric cancer involves:•Muscularis layer• +/- adjacent structures450Pathologic types of early gastric canceraccording to the Japanese classification systemType IType IlaType IlbType IlcType IICancerOMARROWProtrudedMucosaSubmucosaMuscularispropriaElevatedMucosaSubmucosaMuscularispropriaFlatMucosaSubmucosaMuscularispropriaDepressedMucosaSubmucosaMuscularispropriaExcavatedMucosaSubmucosaMuscularispropria

questions.question: An Asian man who is a known smoker presented to the OPD with dysphagia, nausea, and lossof appetite. Endoscopy revealed a tumor arising from the stomach. Which of the followingstatements is false regarding TNM staging for this condition?

options.A: In T4 lesions, tumor perforates the serosa.
options.B: Metastasis in 1-5 lymph nodes is N1 disease.
options.C: Tumor invades adjacent organs in T4 lesions.
options.D: Metastasis in > 15 lymph nodes is N3b.

questions.explanation: The clinical features and endoscopy findings point to a diagnosis of gastric carcinoma. Accordingto TNM staging of gastric carcinoma, N1 disease refers to metastasis to 1-2 regional lymph nodes.

questions.question: A positive Troisier's sign refers to the involvement of which of the following?
questions.explanation: Troisier's sign refers to the enlargement of left supraclavicular lymph nodes, which is also knownas Virchow nodes. It is seen in patients with gastric cancer metastasis, caused by the spread of thetumor via the thoracic duct into the left supraclavicular lymph nodes. It is a sign of advancedcancer.It is one of the atypical presentations of gastric carcinoma. Other atypical presentations of gastriccarcinoma include•Sister Mary Joseph nodule••• Due to periumbilical metastasis.See in both gastric cancer (most common) and ovarian cancer.• Krukenberg's tumor•Bilateral ovarian metastasis• Due to retrograde lymphatic spread• Irish nodule• Left axillary lymphadenopathy.• Blumer shelf nodules• Pelvic metastasis into the pouch of Douglas/ retrovesical pouch451•Sign of advanced gastric carcinoma• Felt on digital palpation• Trosseau syndrome• Migratory thrombophlebitis• Leser Trelet sign• Multiple seborrheic keratoses•Resolves after gastrectomy•Tripe palms• Hyperkeratosis palm.The image below shows an elderly man with left supraclavicular lymph nodes enlarged.

questions.question: 444A male patient who was diagnosed with early gastric cancer is planned for endoscopicmucosal resection. Which of the following features would make him a poor candidate for thisprocedure?
questions.explanation: Endoscopic mucosal resection for gastric cancer should not be performed in case of ulceratedgastric cancer.Indications for endoscopic resection of early gastric cancer:•• Tumor smaller than 2cm• Tumor limited to the mucosa• No lymphovascular invasion• No ulceration• Well or moderately well-differentiated histopathology.Ifany of these are not fulfilled, then gastrectomy with lymph node dissection is indicated.452For a proximal gastric carcinoma a total gastrectomy is done and for distal gastric carcinoma,subtotal gastrectomy is ideal. For advanced carcinoma gastrectomy can be done as a palliativetreatment.

questions.question: A patient with gastric adenocarcinoma is posted for surgery. What is the extent of negativemargin you should remove around the tumor for this patient?
questions.explanation: In surgical resection of gastric cancer, at least 5cm of negative margin should be removed aroundthe tumor.

questions.question: A patient presented with vague abdominal pain and feeling of a lump in the abdomen for thepast 1 year. He was found to have a tumor arising from the stomach on CT scan. Biopsy of thelesion showed tumor cells positive for CD117 and CD34. What is the most likely origin of thetumor?
questions.explanation: The clinical and histopathological features are suggestive of gastrointestinal stromal tumor(GIST). They arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal.453

questions.question: Which of the following is not a component of Carney's triad?
questions.explanation: Carney's triad does not include pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Carney's triad consists of: • Extra-adrenal paraganglioma • Gastrointestinal stromal tumor • Pulmonary chondroma

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with epigastric pain and intermittent vomiting for 2 months. Hewas inadequately treated for H. pylori infection 3 months back. The patient is HIV positiveand is on ART for the same. Endoscopy reveals a fungating mass arising from the stomach.Biopsy of the lesion shows tumor cells positive for CD20. Which of the following is falseregarding this tumor?

options.A: Stomach is the most common organ involved.
options.C: Fundus is the most common site involved
options.D: It is associated with H. pylori infections

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of gastric lymphoma.The most common type of gastric lymphoma is non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL). Among NHL,the most common type is diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) (55%), followed by gastricmucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma, Burkitt lymphoma, mantle cell andfollicular lymphoma.Immunodeficiencies and H. pylori infections are risk factors for the development of primarydiffuse large B-cell lymphoma.The antrum is the most common site for gastric lymphoma. The stomach is the most commonorgan to develop lymphoma in the GI system.Treatment:• Combined modality - chemotherapy, surgery, and/or radiotherapy• The most common chemotherapeutic combination for DLBCL is R-CHOP [Rituximab,Cyclophosphamide, Hydroxydaunomycin (doxorubicin), Oncovin (vincristine), prednisone].

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indication for surgery in a patient with gastric lymphoma?
questions.explanation: Intractable pain is not an indication for surgery in the case of gastric lymphoma.•Indications for surgery in gastric lymphoma:• Patients with symptomatic recurrence or treatment failure• Patients who develop complications, such as bleeding, gastric outlet obstruction, and perforation

questions.question: 446A woman underwent a total gastrectomy 5 months ago for gastric carcinoma. Which of thefollowing is the most common metabolic complication expected in her?
questions.explanation: The most common metabolic complication seen after gastrectomy is iron deficiency anemia.454Although absorption of iron occurs primarily in the duodenum and proximal jejunum, it needs anoptimum acidic environment for absorption. Hence, due to a combination of decreased ironintake, impaired iron absorption, and chronic blood loss, there is iron deficiency anemia. Theaddition of iron supplements to the patient's diet corrects iron deficiency anemia.Complications of gastrectomy:•Dumping syndrome: early and late• Nutritional deficiencies- Iron deficiency anemia (most common), Vit B12 deficiency, andosteoporosis• Diarrhea• Duodenal stump leak/blow out• Bile reflux gastritis and esophagitis• Gall stones• Roux syndrome

questions.question: A 50-year-old male presented with upper GI bleeding, abdominal pain, and a palpableabdominal mass. An endoscopic biopsy revealed a 5 cm tumor, with a high mitotic rate andc-KIT positivity in the body of the stomach. Which of the following is the best treatment ofchoice?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of GIST with a high risk of malignancy (high mitotic rate).The best treatment modality in the given scenario is surgical resection (with negative margin)followed by imatinib. Imatinib is a tyrosine-kinase inhibitor.Option A: Surgical resection + surveillance is done for GIST with a low risk of malignancy. Therisk of malignancy is determined by 2 factors - the size of the tumor and mitotic index.Option C: Lymphadenectomy (D2 gastrectomy) is not done in GIST as it does not show lymphnode metastasis.Option D: GIST is radioresistant and does not respond to conventional chemotherapy. It onlyresponds to imatinib. If imatinib resistant, sunitinib or sorafenib is given.

questions.question: The gastrectomy specimen of a 56-year-old woman who underwent total gastrectomy showedHER2/neu positivity. Which among the following is the drug of choice for the treatment ofthis patient?
questions.explanation: Trastuzumab is the drug of choice in carcinoma stomach with HER2/neu mutation. Trastuzumabis a HER2 receptor antagonist.Chemotherapy options in carcinoma stomach:• With HER2/neu mutation - Trastuzumab/Herceptin• With PD-L1 gene mutation - Pembrolizumab• Oral chemotherapy drugs:• Tegafur• Oteracil• Gimeracil455• Conventional chemotherapy drugs used are 5-fluorouracil and cisplatin.Chemotherapy is offered for patients with lymph node-positive disease and advanced gastriccarcinoma (T3 and beyond) as part of palliative treatment.456
